entry.content:
Our client has completed the sales order process: the ordered goods have been delivered and the customer invoice has already been issued. However, only part of the quantity originally requested for one line item was delivered. Therefore, a smaller quantity than originally requested remains to be fulfilled. They would now like to deliver the remaining quantity, but the original sales order has been completed and cannot be modified.

Is there any way to handle this situation?

entry.title: Re: SAP public cloud RAP Custom action Print pdf
entry.content:
Hi @JamesG

In summary, once you have created the print action in your RAP Behaviour Definition, the corresponding backend logic is implemented in the Behaviour Implementation Class (<your_behaviour_impl_class>) and not in the CDS entity itself.

The CDS entity (DEFINE ROOT VIEW ENTITY...) only holds structural definitions. It is not responsible for handling the action logic or storing transient content like a PDF binary.

Have a look at the following references and Blog for further details.

Comparing ABAP Restful Application Programming (RAP) model with the Cloud Application Programming (CAP) model, Business Object Implementation Types, ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

Behavior Extensions, Defining Actions as Part of the Behavior Definition

Simplifying Attachment Downloads in RAP with CDS Views: A Step-by-Step Guide

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to Integrate SAP BTP Cloud Logging Service with SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) Using SAML
entry.content:
Dear SAP Cloud Logging users,

We (SAP Cloud Logging team) cross-checked with BTP Security team on the general guidance: SAML and OIDC are both supported protocols. The general guidance to prefer OIDC is/was primarily targeting "Application Users" and not to the entire BTP.

As @shusei_sekiya rightly pointed out, SAP Cloud Logging does not support OIDC for external customers yet. The enablement of OIDC will follow the major version update for OpenSearch to 2.x (phase 3) which is planned for early December. So, the tentative timeline for OIDC would be early next year.

Details can be found is What's new with SAP Cloud Logging section.

Thanks, 
SAP Cloud Logging team

entry.title: Re: SAP B1 Web Client 2508
entry.content:
In 2508 we Choose From List control was introduced.
You can find it here:
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_BUSINESS_ONE_WEB_CLIENT/e6ac71d18c7543828bd4463f77d67ff7/e060bc9215314528887f925e9b585733.html?locale=en-US&version=10.0_SP_2508

it enables multi-selection by setting the property "multiSelection" in the JSON:

"multiSelection": true

In order to process the returned values, the "change" event should be implemented.
I tested successfully the following code:

async onTestMultiSelect(oEnv, oEvent) {
      const value = oEvent.getParameter('value'); // Object with selected items
      const oView = await oEnv.ActiveView();
     
      if (value && typeof value === 'object' && Object.keys(value).length > 0) {
        // Extract item codes from the object structure
        const itemCodes = Object.values(value).map(item => item.value);
        const itemNames = Object.values(value).map(item => `${item.value} - ${item.rowValue.ItemName}`);
       
        const message = `You selected ${itemCodes.length} item(s): ${itemNames.join(' ')}`;
        await oEnv.showMessageBox("Multi-Selection Result", message);
       
        // Update the static text display
        const currentData = await oView.getCustomizedData("data");
        currentData.SelectedItems = itemCodes.join(', ');
        await oView.setCustomizedData(currentData, "data");
       
        // Update the CFL control value to show selected items
        const oCFL = await oView.ChooseFromList("fXbi5iHiSdn2iyMkeyFpgx");
        await oCFL.setValue(itemCodes.join(', '));
      } else {
        await oEnv.showMessageBox("Multi-Selection Result", "No items selected");
       
        // Clear the CFL value if nothing selected
        const oCFL = await oView.ChooseFromList("fXbi5iHiSdn2iyMkeyFpgx");
        await oCFL.setValue("");
      }
    }

 You can also use a dialog form as a pop-up form, and design if with any logic you desire.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_BUSINESS_ONE_WEB_CLIENT/e6ac71d18c7543828bd4463f77d67ff7/6c4ad8a9fc6748c0a678f1463dea9ffe.html?locale=en-US&version=10.0_SP_2508

entry.title: Business rule for Variable Pay and/or Rewards&Recognition that are using data from custom MDF
entry.content:
Hello,

-> I have the following case for VP. Client has several eligibility conditions for VP, and one of them is looking at the absences of the employees. Since there are struggles in using data from Time Off Module into the the VP and COMP, we have build a custom MDF which will be used by the client to upload the total number of absence days for each employee. Then our idea was to use this MDF in the business rule so that we inlcude in VP (Employee history from EC) only those employees that have a certain amount of absence days in that MDF or don't have any absence days there. However, when I tried to build a business rule (VP scenario) I don't get the expected result, I can't identify which function I should use in the business rule so that rule reads the MDF object correctly.

-> Similar struggle I encountered with the Rewards and Recognition. The case there is that employees who has a disciplinary action in the previous 6 month shouldn't be eligible for SPOT award. In order to store data on those disciplinary actions we have a custom MDF object, and then in the business rule (Rewards and Recognition scenario) I wanted to build the logic to look at the effective date of the disciplinary actions from that MDF, saying that if effective date of the actions is earlier than previous 6 month then employee is eligble, else employee is not eligible (this seems to work), and an additional condition would be OR if employee doesn't have any disciplinary actions then employees is eligible (and this second condition I can't make it work).

Anyone had similar cases maybe, or managed to build a rules using the data from MDF object, that would actually work? Or should I maybe use "Rules for MDF Objects" scenario for the business rule in order to have it functioning properly?

Many thanks!

entry.title: Re: Extending Entitlements for aem-validation-service-pla...
entry.content: Hi @MioYasutake, To integrate CAP with AEM, both an aem-validation-service instance (with the aem-validation-service-plan) and a User-Provided Service (UPS) are required. If the CAP application resides in a different subaccount, you need to create a lightweight version of the aem-validation-service (still using the aem-validation-service-plan) and configure it with handshake credentials. This is necessary because the CAP plugin first looks for an instance of the aem-validation-service with the aem-validation-service-plan and retrieves the credentials from there. Therefore, my question is whether this plan can extend entitlements to another subaccount (where the CAP app is deployed) without incurring additional costs.

entry.title: Automating the Extraction of SAP CI DS security audit logs to SPLUNK
entry.content:
Hi,

Currently we are automating the security audit log extraction of all apps used in our organization to SPLUNK for security and auditing purposes. One such application in SAP CI DS.

But unlike other SAP applications (SAP IAS,workzone,CPI) CI DS does not have any API exposed publicly. We have referred to the below community post as well wherein it is mentioned that no API available to fetch security logs.

 Solved: How-to export CI-DS Logs to external system - SAP Community

Hence, we tried to raise a ticket with SAP and we have got suggestion to do web scraping as no other options found. 

We have conducted further analysis and obtained the internal URL from the web browser's network capture. We discovered the get_log method, which retrieves all the audit log details.
URL:
https://[your-instance].hana.ondemand.com/DSoD/security_admin/get_log?pageNum=1&selected_event_type_id=4&event_time_period_id=2&event_user_name_filter=&event_object_name_filter=&timezoneid=null&startTimeHour=1&startTimeMin=1&startTimeAmPm=0&startTimeYear=2025&startTimeMonth=10&startTimeDate=30&endTimeHour=12&endTimeMin=59&endTimeAmPm=1&endTimeYear=2025&endTimeMonth=11&endTimeDate=6&_=1762445363085
 
We have tried to hit the get_log  url from external tool (insomnia).
  • We used the session ID (JSESSIONID) from an active CI-DS browser session and passed it in the request headers.
  • This approach works for short-term testing but has major limitations:
    • Session IDs expire quickly and require manual refresh.
    • Sharing session IDs is not secure and violates best practices.
    • Cannot be used for long-term automation or external system integration.
 
Current Limitation
  • The get_log method is an internal UI API and does not officially support OAuth2 tokens or non-interactive access.
  • Even after obtaining an OAuth token from SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS), the endpoint redirects to the CI-DS login page, indicating that it only accepts browser-based SAML authentication.
  • This makes it impossible to integrate with external systems for automated log extraction using standard API authentication.
Is there any option to overcome the authorization issue to access the get_log url ?If not is there any standard web scraping tool available to achieve this, if so can we please get the details and the steps to achieve the same.
 
Regards,
Gayathri Ravi

entry.title: SAP RPT-1: Ready-to-Use AI for Structured Data
entry.content:
Hi all,

as you may have heared, SAP recently introduced RPT-1 (Relational Pre-Trained Transformer).  To explore how well the model will work and if it is able to return different outputs, I integrated it into a small SAP CAP application. My choosen dataset contains historical data with sample customer pizza orders (order day, order time, pizza type, order quantity, etc.).

The goal: predict each customer’s next order day and next pizza type 🍕.

RPT-1 in Action 

A standard Fiori Elements list report displays the historical data that serves as input. When the user selects a customer and clicks “Trigger Prediction,” the CAP backend sends data to the RPT-1 API and receives the predicted results. These are then shown in charts within a dialog.

Short program flow overview:

  1. CAPreads historical order data from (HANA-) DB
  2. Backend constructs the payload that RPT-1 expects. (API key and endpoint details can be found in the official documentation.)
  3. Model returns predicted columns (next_day, next_pizza). These fields must exist in the data structure as well
  4. Backend merges historical data and prediction results
  5. Frontend visualizes both predicted sets using VizFrame charts

I found it very useful to try out RPT-1 in the Playground first before building a full application. Here you can experiment with your dataset and understand the prediction behavior as well as how you might need to adjust your data set to get the desired outcomes.

If you are are curious like me how that works in CAP, I have listed my doings below:

Set up your environment - Use SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) or VS Code with the SAP Fiori and CAP extensions installed. Create a new CAP project or a Full-Stack application using the Productivity Tools

Prepare your data - Create a CSV file with columns like customer, order_day, pizza_type, quantity, etc., and deploy it to your database (SQLite or SAP HANA using cds deploy --to hana / sqllite: db.sqlite

Get access to RPT-1 - Use the API endpoint: https://rpt.cloud.sap/api/predict The API token is available on the SAP RPT-1 documentation page (after logging in with your S-user)

Prepare the payload & Call the RPT-1 API  - I tried to get the payload in the form like mentioned in the documentation

const historic = await SELECT.from(HistoricalData);  
const trainRows = historic
      // optionally focus payload on one customer:
      .filter(r => !focusCustomer || r.customer_id === focusCustomer)

      .map(r => ({
        customer_id: r.customer_id,
        pizza_name: r.pizza_name,
        order_day: r.order_day,
        next_order_day: r.next_order_day,
        next_pizza_name: r.next_pizza_name
      }));​

Screenshot from expected payload:

Do not forget to provide the data set which you want to predict (normally that is all in your initial data set and marked with "[PREDICT]", but to explicitly show it, I also hardcoded one line of data where I want to get the prediction results)

  const predictRows = [
      { customer_id: focusCustomer, pizza_name: "Margherita", order_day: "Thu", next_order_day: "[PREDICT]", next_pizza_name: "[PREDICT]" }
    ]

Constructed Payload in the service.js file

 const payload = {
      rows: [...trainRows, ...predictRows],
      index_column: "customer_id"
  };​

Once these preparation steps are done , I used axios to call the above described API route (remember to get you API Token)

    try {
      const response = await axios.post(API_URL, payload, {
        headers: {
          "Authorization": `Bearer ${TOKEN}`,
          "Content-Type": "application/json",
        },
      });
     console.log("Prediction result:", JSON.stringify(response.data, null, 2));
    } catch (error) {
      console.error("RPT-1 error:", error.response?.data || error.message);
      };
    }

Once the API call was successful, the API returns a json object (including your historical send data along with the prediction result). Here an extract of the payload I received: 

Prediction result: {
  "prediction": {
    "id": "782d5f80-0dd3-4b06-a589-985cfe5a41db",
    "metadata": {
      "num_columns": 4,
      "num_predict_rows": 3,
      "num_predict_tokens": 6,
      "num_rows": 24
    },
    "predictions": [
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "next_order_day": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Sat"
          }
        ],
        "next_pizza_name": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Seafood Special"
          }
        ]
      },
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "next_order_day": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Thu"
          }
        ],
        "next_pizza_name": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Margherita"
          }
        ]
      },
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "next_order_day": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Sun"
          }
        ],
        "next_pizza_name": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Margherita"
          }
        ]
      }
    ]
  },
  "delay": 272.4773660004139,
  "aiApiRequestPayload": {
    "prediction_config": {
      "target_columns": [
        {
          "name": "next_order_day",
          "placeholder_value": "[PREDICT]",
          "task_type": "classification"
        },
        {
          "name": "next_pizza_name",
          "placeholder_value": "[PREDICT]",
          "task_type": "classification"
        }
      ]
    },
    "rows": [ //rows which where present here in my historical data
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "pizza_name": "Seafood Special",
        "order_day": "Sun",
        "next_order_day": "Sat",
        "next_pizza_name": "Margherita"
      }, ... // more rows

In case you care only about the preduction result (for further processing) you will find that in: 

predictions = response.data.prediction.predictions
"predictions": [
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "next_order_day": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Sat"
          }
        ],
        "next_pizza_name": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Seafood Special"
          }
        ]
      },
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "next_order_day": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Thu"
          }
        ],
        "next_pizza_name": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Margherita"
          }
        ]
      },
      {
        "customer_id": "C004",
        "next_order_day": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Sun"
          }
        ],
        "next_pizza_name": [
          {
            "confidence": null,
            "prediction": "Margherita"
          }
        ]
      }
    ]

Eventhough we have the predicted results,  in most of the cases we want to combine the hostorical data with predicted results, to display a kind of graphical trend / relation. 

In my case, to get the shown graphs which could be the next potential order day and the next potential pizza, I combined the data in an object and returned it to my Handler.js file. To get the desired outcome within the graphical illustration later in the front-end I returned the predicted and historical data like this: 

let returnObject = {
      customerId: focusCustomer,
      history: {
        byDay: historyByDay,       // e.g., bind to series “History”
        byPizza: historyByPizza
      },
      predictions: {
        rows: predsForCustomer,    // raw rows if you want a details table
        top: { day: topDay, pizza: topPizza }, // for highlight
        byDay: predictedByDay,     // e.g., 2nd series “Predicted” on the weekday chart
        byPizza: predictedByPizza  // e.g., overlay or stacked series on pizza chart
      }
    }

Visualize the results - The returned JSON I used as a basis to construct the graphical illustration in the front end. In the Handler.js I filled a JSON model with the data recieved from the backend (above JSON object) and wired the XML Fragement around it

Conclusion 

Including RPT-1  in a CAP app seemed very smooth. Especially all the  important information (like API Keys, API Route, Payload Structure) was easy to find. During the development I still had in the back of my mind when to use other SAP provided services which  seems to be similar (like Data Attribute Reccomondation for instance). I know other services are more focused on the full ML life cycle (i have my own model, training iterations, etc.) but sometimes I am wondering with all the available services, which tool to choose from the big toolbox SAP provides. 

From a first sight, I feel that with such a quick integration option like with RPT-1 I can cover 70-80% of use cases. At least to get accurate results in a very short time. Still I believe for data specific use cases, where I want to use my own trained model, Data Attribute Recommondation would be still my preferred option.

Please share your opinion as well for which use cases you use which kind of services

Since this is my first SAP Community article, I’d be happy to receive your feedback. Let me know in the comments how you see RPT-1 and the new doors it opens for enterprise AI.

entry.title: Re: Delta (statistical) depreciation areas missing in SAP...
entry.content:
Hi @maekman

Your question did not get to me. Please ensure you use the @links to ensure it gets to the intended person.

To summarise, in public cloud, Sweden does not have pre-delivered statistical depreciation areas because SAP’s local template assumes that the difference between local tax and book depreciation is handled manually in accordance with Swedish legal and accounting requirements.

Since configuration activity 105494 is display-only in public cloud, you cannot create a new depreciation area such as statistical deltas. Considering the public cloud adheres to a clean-core approach, it sets localisation boundaries, meaning all additional statistical areas must either:

  • Be part of the delivered localisation, or
  • Be handled manually through reporting and adjustment postings in the General Ledger (AA subledger alignment).

Below is a guided step to handle the posting.

First, you need to identify the Difference Using the Standard Report. In the Asset History Sheet app, run the report for your company code and fiscal year-end. Compare Depreciation Area 15, which is Local T and Depreciation Area 32 which is Book. Then extract the delta, this is the amount to post for each asset.

Second, is to create a Manual Adjustment Posting in the Post General Journal Entries app. Enter your Swedish company code, enter Posting Date. Debit/Credit the relevant depreciation expense accounts, assign the posting to Ledger Group=2L to restrict impact to local GAAP only.

Third, is to reconcile in Asset Accounting subledger by using the Manage Fixed Assets app. Check the depreciation posted for each area. Use your manual journal as a reconciliation item between Depreciation Area 15 and 32. Attach the journal entry ID in your year-end workpaper for audit.

Optionally (step 4), you can automate reporting. To do that, created a Custom Analytical Query based on CDS view I_AssetBalanceCube. Add DepreciationArea and AmountType dimensions. Filter Area 15 and 32, calculate delta through a formula. This report gives you a ready dataset for your year-end manual posting.

Next step is maintaining the G/L Accounts. Either you create or reuse G/L accounts for Expense, Accumulated Depreciation, or maintain these in your Chart of Accounts.

 

Apologies for the wrong link.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

Example: Parallel Accounting and the Derived Depreciation Area, Parallel Accounting in Asset Accounting,

Depreciation Areas, Parallel Accounting, Ledger Scenarios, Depreciation Posting Run

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Migrating SAP PI/PO XI Proxy scenarios to Integration Suite – Key considerations and recommendat
entry.content:
Hi,

Amazing Blog, @arunmaarirajha_kv .

entry.title: How to handle fixed asset impairment in S/4HANA Public Cloud (US GAAP)?
entry.content:
We are implementing SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and we want to know how to handle impairment of fixed assets.

Our accounting principle is USAP(US GAAP), and in depreciation area 34(Book Depreciation), it seems that asset revaluation is not allowed. In on-premise or private cloud, we can set the flag "Post Revaluation" in transaction code OAYR, but in S/4HANA Public Cloud this option is not available.

As an alternative, we are considering unplanned depreciation, but we understand that impairment and unplanned depreciation are conceptually different.
Should we use unplanned depreciation, or is there another recommended way to reflect the impairment loss under US GAAP?

Thank you for your insights.

entry.title: PY-TH: Navigating the Tax Deduction Maze of Diverse Employee Funds
entry.content:
The Thailand Payroll Team is preparing for the implementation of a new government scheme, the Employee Welfare Fund (EWF), to comply with the act issued by the Ministry of Labour.

Although the fund was initially scheduled to affect all companies in Thailand starting October 2025, the Thai cabinet approved and Ministry of Labour announced a one-year postponement in August 2025. This crucial decision shifts the mandatory compliance date to October 2026 and provides the payroll team with additional time to fully understand the EWF and prepare for its operational management.

Before diving into the details of the EWF, it is essential to first establish why this new compliance is so important for the Thailand payroll function. 

The Diverse Employee Fund in Net Income Calculation

When an employer pays salary to employees, the payroll administrator must calculate the net taxable income and the tax amount to determine the final net income (Net Pay) that employees receive at the end of month. This is the high level formula used to calculate Net Income.

I mapped the net pay formula to the pay slip for better understanding and highlighted the fund contribution amount (No.4 in the picture) in this blog.

Most companies in Thailand are required to contribute the Provident Fund and Social Security fund. The term "most" is used because the Provident fund is optional for employers, and public sector companies are excluded from Social Security Fund as they have their own health benefits. Nevertheless, if your company falls under this category, your payroll team must manage these two funds to comply with Thai law. There are other types of funds in Thailand that your payroll team needs to manage. I categorized the Fund in Thailand related to permanent employee in three groups.

Group 1 - Most companies in Thailand must  submit information to the government departments and Fund managers after payroll calculation. Social Security Fund of Social Security Office (SSO) , Provident Fund (PVD) , Student Loan Fund (SLF) , Worker's Compensation Fund Social Security Office (WCF) , Employee Welfare Fund (EWF).

Group 2 - These funds apply to specific industries. If your company operates as public sector organization or private school, you will need to manage these funds. Government Pension Fund (GPF) , Government Permanent Employee Registered Provident Fund (GPEF), Private Teacher Aid Fund.

Group 3 - These are mutual funds that employees invest in themselves. Payroll team needs to take action when employees declare their investments for tax exemption purposes. Examples include the Retirement Mutual Fund (RMF) and Thai Environment Social Governance Fund (Thai ESG) - SAP Note 3409981 - for tax year 2025 onward. In the previous tax year, Long Term Equity Fund (LTF) and Super Saving Fund (SSF) were also part of tax exemption schemes. For more details, SAP Payroll Thailand.

This is an overview information of the diverse employee funds in Thailand. Next we dive into what we started, Employee Welfare Fund (EWF). We developed and released to our customers in August 2025 before the original effective date in October 2025, and we will continue to keep it updated for the new effective date of October 2026. To increase Thailand payroll team confidence and understand solution and how to configure.

Employee Welfare Fund Payroll Process Guide

1. Legal and Calculation Requirement Monthly process Both the employee and the employer equal monthly contributions at EWF's fixed rate of employee's based income.

Contribution Formula:

Submission Deadline: The Payroll team must submit the EWF Contribution Report (SKL3) and the corresponding contribution amount to EWF by the 15th of the following month.

2. Data Maintenance in the Payroll Solution

Defining Based Income Amount (No 2), the based income amount is calculated by assigning relevant income Wagetypes to Cumulation Class no 44. These assinged Wagetypes will be summed up to form the basis for the EWF calculation.

This is company or business specific requirement. The Thailand payroll team needs to confirm with Employee Welfare Fund which income types are defined as the based income. Check your income Wagetypes and ensure they are configured in Cumulation Class no 44. (using table V_T512W_D or report program RPDLGA20)

EWF's Monthly Contribution Rate (No 3), The EWF contribution rate is announced by the Ministry of Labour. This rate is maintained in a standard system table (V_T511K). The system accessed this rate when the Wagetypes MW01 is maintained in the employee data and calculates during the payroll run. Any legal changes to the rate will be released on the SAP Note for you to apply.

Identifying EWF Members, Only employees who are active EWF members are included in the calculation. The Payroll team must maintain the membership data using the standard Wagetype MW01 which set in Processing Class No 68. The system will only process contributions for employees who have this data maintained in Infotype 0014Recurring Payment/Deduction.

Note: If the Wagetype does not appear in the payroll log verify that Processing Class 68 of MW01 is set correctly. (the default setting should be correct).

3. Monthly Payroll Calculation

During the monthly payroll run, the system executes a function for the EWF calculation. 

Payroll Function: The system calculates the final EWF contribution amount the specific payroll function name THEWF.

Verification: The Payroll team can verify the calculation result and breakdown in the payroll log. (See SAP Note 3598469 for detailed payroll calculation information).

 

4. Reporting and Submission

The final step is generating the required report for official submission. One key information in the report is Business Category that you should configure in V_T7THBR table.

 

Report Generation: The payroll team can generate the official report using the transaction code PC00_M26_CEWF. This program generate the result in ALV layout and PDF format. More detail information for report SAP Note 3628546

 

The configuration guide and solution information will help your Thailand Payroll Team be ready to operate Employee Welfare Fund (EWF) for your employees in October 2026. Should there be any legal changes before October 2026, the solution will be updated and released on SAP Regulatory Change Manager. For more details about HCM Thailand, refer to SAP Regional Collaboration Workzone Groups - Thailand.

HCM Payroll #HCM Payroll Thailand Localization

entry.title: Hire Template Configuration: Supported MDF Object Types and Implementation Guidelines for Onboarding
entry.content:
Introduction: 

When configuring the New Hire Data Review or Personal Data Collection pages in SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding, we observe that data from effective-dated custom MDF objects does not propagate correctly to Employee Central.

In some cases, the following issues may occur:

  • Data entered in Onboarding does not appear in the Manage Pending Hires (MPH) page.
  • Information captured during Onboarding is missing or overwritten once the candidate is converted to an employee.
  • Custom fields linked to effective-dated MDF objects fail to display or save values correctly in Onboarding forms.
  • Unexpected behavior or data inconsistencies are noticed when using effective-dated entities that are originally configured in Employee Central but reused in Onboarding.

Why do we see such data inconsistencies?

This behavior typically occurs because SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding supports only non-effective dated MDF objects, due to its dependency on external user context, unlike Employee Central where effective-dated entities are supported.

What is the Supported Configuration in Onboarding?

  • Onboarding users (external candidates) do not yet have a full employee profile or time context as in Employee Central.
  • Hence the supported type is Non-Effective Dated Custom MDF Objects only.
    How to add this Configuration:
  • When defining the MDF object under Configure Object Definitions, set Effective Dating to None.
  • Add the object to the New Hire Template → Data Review Page or Personal Data Collection Page.

Why Onboarding Does Not Support Effective-Dated Entities:

  • Onboarding operates within the external user context, where users are not yet fully active employees.
  • Effective-dated entities require Employee Central user context to manage date-driven records.
  • Since the Onboarding process is provisional, effective-dating logic cannot be applied.
  • Once the user transitions to EC, effective-dated MDF Objects can be used for ongoing employee data management.

What is the recommended approach when configure New Hire Templates including custom MDF Objects for Onboarding?

  • Always use non-effective-dated MDF Objects for Onboarding.
  • If you already have effective-dated custom objects in New Hire Template (Onboarding):
    • Create a duplicate non-effective-dated object (copy the structure but change Effective Dating → None).
    • Map this object in the New Hire Template under the relevant section (Data Review or Personal Data Collection).
    • Keep the EC effective-dated version for post-hire data synchronization.

What behaviour change was introduced in 2H 2025 Release to avoid using effective dated custom objects in New Hire Template:

  • Previously, there was no error message to inform the administrator that the Hire Template doesn't support non-effective dated custom MDF objects.
  • Currently, an error message informs the administrator that the Hire Template supports only non-effective dated custom MDF objects. 
  • Guide link for reference: Minor Visual Changes in 2H 2025 | SAP Help Portal
Frequently Asked Questions:
  • If we change the effective dating setting from “Effective-Dated” to “None,” will existing data be lost?
    The data should not be lost when effective dating is set to “None”. However, we would recommend creating a new object and avoid making changes to the existing object.

  • After switching to “None” for effective dating, will the custom MDF objects stop mapping correctly to the Employee Profile?
    The data flow to Employee Profile will not be withheld. Since this is the recommended approach, there will not be any data loss when propagating to EC.

  • If we are currently using effective-dated MDF entities without encountering any issues. Under what specific scenarios or configurations do data loss or data propagation issues occur?
    There is no definitive scenario for which the data wipe out issues occur and since we do not support effective dated custom MDF Objects in Onboarding it is not possible to for us to determine the root cause. The correct way to configure the new hire template is available in the guide: Configuring Hire Template for Access New Hire

entry.title: Re: Timeouts When Maintaining Large Business Roles in S/4...
entry.content:
Dear @Mike_vanIngen,

  • The timeouts you’re seeing are a known limitation when a single business role contains a very large number of business catalogs. SAP’s official guidance is to split the mega-role into several smaller roles and avoid editing roles with 1000+ catalogs.

Please check SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3648696

 

  • Create From Template”doesn’t accept a user-defined upload file. It’s only for SAP-delivered Business Role Templates (you pick a template in the app and the system copies its catalogs/restrictions). If you want to reuse a role you built, use Download/Upload Business Roles (XML) or transport it via Software Collections not Create From Template.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/8980ad05330b4585ab96a8e09cef4688.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/a58f69585339484aa204cf0321cab2cd.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/83c1cd62666f48c68d93f2fdeae1ae95.html

My suggestion and practical workarounds:

  • Replace the single super-role with a “bundle” of smaller roles Break catalogs by LoB (e.g., Finance, MM, SD, WM, Analytics), by scope item groups, or by technology (GUI/Fiori) depending on how you troubleshoot.
  • Use tooling to find missing authorizations instead of blanket access Display Authorization Trace app activate a trace for the affected business user, have them reproduce the issue, then review failed checks and fix just the needed catalogs/restrictions.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/79b3c9b7701248fe83b81d4b15134e8d.html

  • IAM Information System + Business Catalogs: look up an app → see its required business catalogs and scope-item ties, then adjust roles precisely. This is SAP’s recommended route after upgrades when tiles “disappear”. More details in SAP Note’s:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2602149

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3462922

  • SAP’s own guidance after upgrades: review and adapt business roles rather than grant everything. More details on SAP Community:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/review-and-adapt-business-roles-after-a-major-upgrade-in-the-sap-s-4hana/ba-p/13636083

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Customer Payments – Transition and Future with APIs
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Customer Payments - Transition and Future with APIs

SAP has transitioned SAP Cloud for Customer Payments into maintenance mode and removed it from the price list (as of September 2, 2024). The solution will continue to be supported for existing customers under active contracts, but no further development or investments are made. Customers are encouraged to transition to the new API-based approach in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and On-Premise/Private Cloud.

Accounts receivable processes today are often costly, manual, and time-consuming. Many businesses face delays in cash collection, lack of transparency for their customers, and high operational costs for invoice and payment handling.

With the new S/4HANA APIs, SAP enables customers and partners to build modern customer-facing portals that accelerate the invoice-to-cash process and support automated cash collection. These portals empower end customers with self-service capabilities, reducing manual workload while improving the customer experience.

Capabilities Enabled by S/4HANA APIs

Using the APIs already available in S/4HANA On-Premise, Private Cloud, and Public Cloud businesses can:

APIs for Electronic Bill Presentment and Payment

  • Pay & manage bills: Select open items, create payments (via direct debit or credit card when SAP Digital Payments Add-on is integrated), view or cancel payments in process
  • Display account statements: View and download all items for a specific time period for the customer invoice, credit memo, and / or incoming payment(s)

Other APIs

  • Match payments with invoices: Improve reconciliation through payment matching
  • Create and manage payment advice: Issue or cancel payment advice efficiently
  • Make ad-hoc payments: Support payments on account or down payment requests
  • Manage account master data: View and update account and master data directly

These capabilities can be embedded into custom-built portals or integrated into existing customer-facing portals, offering flexibility for each company’s unique landscape.

This new API approach is not a one-to-one successor, but provides greater flexibility:

  • APIs are released for S/4HANA On-Premise, Private Cloud, and Public Cloud (from release 2508.02)
  • Customers can build their own portals, integrate into existing ones, or leverage partner-built portals
  • Partners are actively working with SAP to deliver ready-to-use solutions based on these APIs

Partner Solutions: Ready-to-Use Customer Payment Portals

To help customers accelerate adoption, SAP partners already offer pre-built customer payment and self-service portals leveraging the new APIs.

Kumulon – KUMOsphere B2B Payment Portal

Kumulon delivers a cloud-native, template-based portal built on SAP BTP with full support for SAP’s latest payment APIs.

  • Real cloud services, no legacy code – innovative SAP Cloud technologies only
  • Flexible templates – adapt quickly to customer needs while jumpstarting projects
  • Secure integration – SAP Cloud Connector ensures safe on-premise-to-cloud connectivity
  • Flexible deployment – operate in your own BTP environment or as SaaS on Kumulon’s BTP

🔗 KUMOsphere – B2B Payment Portal on SAP Store

Acuiti Labs – Customer Self Care and Payment Portal

Acuiti Labs offers a SaaS-based self-service and payment portal for S/4HANA Private and Public Cloud (Sales Billing/FI-AR) leveraging the S/4HANA APIs.

  • Customer self-service portal – empowers end customers to manage invoices and payments directly
  • Cross-solution experience – already proven in BRIM (FI-CA), Subscription Billing, and Q2C portals
  • Accelerated go-live – prebuilt solution reduces implementation effort

🔗 Acuiti Labs Customer Portal on SAP Store

Learn More

APIs for Electronic Billing and Presentment – S/4HANA On-Premise (OP), Private Cloud

  • All APIs part of the Electronic Billing and Presentment scope are shipped via SAP Note 3505741
  • For other required APIs outside the package, please see also the SAP Business Accelerator Hub for more details, for example: Managing Payment Advice is available, see Payment Advice (A2X).
  • For more information, visit the SAP Help Portal.

APIs for EBPP Payment Request – S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • Please see the SAP Business Accelerator Hub for the available EBPP Payment Request APIs.
  • For other required APIs outside the package, please see also the SAP Business Accelerator Hub for more details, for example:
    • Match payments with invoices & Create and manage payment advice, Payment Advice.
    • Make ad-hoc payments, Journal Entry -Post
    • Manage account master data, Business Partner
    • Customer account balance, Accounting Document - Read
  • For more information, visit the SAP Help Portal.

Summary

SAP Cloud for Customer Payments is moving into maintenance mode, and the future lies in API-driven, flexible customer payment portals. Customers can now:

  • Plan their transition to S/4HANA API-based solutions
  • Either build their own portals or leverage ready-to-use partner solutions from the SAP Store

This shift gives businesses greater flexibility, faster innovation, and improved customer experiences in the accounts receivable process.

entry.title: Re: Creating the Shell System for SAP Business Transformation Center: A Practical Approach
entry.content:
Hi @dfunkert

Is there any reason to do the Client Copy by remote?
In my projects we do the following:

1. Do a Systemcopy with SUM DMO without Software Change to migrate form anyDB to SAP HANA
2. create a temp client by copy SAP CUST Profile (or whatever you need) from the customer client on Target.
3. Delete customer client on Target
4. Copy back temp Client to customer client
5. Do the conversion to S4 on the Target so it become your shell

Do you see any issues with this approach?

One additional Info:
SWPM is deprecated for Migrations from anyDB to SAP HANA.
SUM DMO without software change is the tool that should be used.

entry.title: Bridging Project Planning: Integrating SAP Cloud ERP with SAP Project and Resource Management (PRM)
entry.content:
As project-driven organizations increasingly adopt SAP Cloud ERP , the need for robust project planning capabilities becomes critical. While SAP Cloud ERP excels in financial, commercial and logistics aspects of project management, SAP Project and Resource Management (PRM) complements the SAP Business Suite—offering scheduling, resource allocation, and project structure capabilities.

This blog provides details on integration relevant features that enables intelligent project execution by importing projects from SAP Cloud ERP into PRM and then proceed with further detailed project planning and scheduling. 

Integration Setup

PRM supports integration with Enterprise Projects as well as Professional Service Projects. There are two ways to integrate with SAP Cloud ERP for the purpose of project planning, execution and scheduling.

  1. Use the recommended approach i.e. Direct Point-Point Integration.
  2. Alternatively, you can establish the integration using SAP Integration Suite.

For organizations evaluating integration options between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Project and Resource Management (PRM), it's important to understand the advantages of each approach and why the direct point-to-point integration is recommended.

Direct Point-to-Point Integration offers seamless synchronization of project data using the Enterprise Project API. This method ensures that project information is always up-to-date between SAP Cloud ERP and PRM, reducing manual data entry and the risk of errors. It supports both enterprise and professional services projects and enables full project management capabilities within PRM, including editing and scheduling of imported project plans. Customers benefit from a streamlined process, improved data accuracy, and the ability to leverage advanced planning  and scheduling features offered by PRM, making it ideal for organizations seeking an integrated and efficient project management workflow.

Integration via SAP Integration Suite provides flexibility for more complex or hybrid system landscapes, especially when connecting to SAP Cloud ERP Private. While this approach may suit organizations with specific middleware or integration requirements, it currently supports only the import of project plans through the “Manage Multiple Project Plans” application. This means that imported plans cannot be edited or scheduled within PRM, potentially limiting the depth of project management and planning capabilities available to users.

In summary, customers using SAP Cloud ERP should choose the recommended direct point-to-point integration because it delivers comprehensive project management functions, enables bi-directional data exchange, and ensures optimal use of PRM’s planning and scheduling tools. The SAP Integration Suite option may be considered for specialized cases but comes with functional limitations that may impact project execution and flexibility.

Detailed Overview 

This section offers a step-by-step walkthrough of the key features that enable project plan integration between SAP Project and Resource Management (PRM) and SAP Cloud ERP, accessible via the “Manage Project Plans” application.

Pre-requisite:

  • You have created either an Enterprise Project with a high level project plan or a PSA Project with few work packages added to it, in SAP Cloud ERP.
  • You have created a Collaborative Project in PRM which we would use further in this blog.

 The next step is to import the Enterprise or PSA Project in SAP Cloud ERP as a project plan within the Collaborative Project in PRM

In “Manage Project Plans” application, start creating a project plan for your Collaborative Project by choosing the option “ From Other System”.

In the pop-up window, the Collaborative Project gets defaulted from the previous selection. The “Source System” field should be showing already the SAP Cloud ERP system that’s configured as active in Business System Configuration application. In case of multiple SAP Cloud ERP systems configured in PRM as active, you can select the one from the drop down list from which you want to import the project.

By default, the “Related Object”(Created in Collaborative Project) checkbox field is selected. When you click on “Go”, the system shows a list of projects based on the Related Objects of object type “Project” that you would have created earlier for the collaborative project as shown in the “Related Objects” screenshot below. This allows you to quickly choose a project from the list without searching for it and proceed with project plan creation

If there are no Related Objects created prior to this step, then you can deselect the “Related Object”(Created in Collaborative Project) checkbox and start to search the projects by choosing the value help provided for “Project from Source System”. You can type in a search term which can either be the project ID or Name . Select a project and click on “Continue”

Hint : While searching projects, the system uses “Enterprise Project” API to communicate with the corresponding source SAP Cloud ERP system and hence the list would show both Professional Services projects as well as Enterprise Projects.

In the next screen, system shows a preview of things that will be done by the system. Choose “Create” to finish importing the project as a project plan in PRM.

You can see that the project structure(Work Packages and Milestones) from the source system has been imported along with the scheduling relevant information like Planned Start , Planned Finish dates . The duration field shows the calculated number of days between the start and finish dates.

Navigation links to Source System

If the project that you imported is an Enterprise Project, you can navigate to the corresponding Project Briefs app or the WBS Element by clicking on the hyperlink provided for each element in the project structure

If the project that you imported is a Professional Services Project, the project structure would contain the relevant Work Packages and Billing Elements. You can navigate to the corresponding project in the “Project Control- Professional Services Projects” application by clicking on relevant hyperlinks in the project structure.

Keeping PRM and SAP Cloud ERP Projects in Sync

When you Edit Project Plan in the Manage Project Plans app, the system first validates whether any incremental changes have been made to the corresponding source project in the SAP Cloud ERP system by any user. If such updates exist, the user is prompted to Receive Updates before proceeding, ensuring that the version being edited reflects the latest data from the source project.

The Sync Actions button in the Manage Project Plans app provides three key options that control how schedule data is exchanged between systems.

  • Receive Updates – pulls the latest project structure information from the source project in SAP Cloud ERP into PRM, ensuring that the project plan in PRM reflects the most current version.
  • Send Updates – pushes date changes made in PRM. Ideally this is not needed to be used until there are some error situations in date synchronization, in which case the user will be shown the messages in the project plan application.
  • Check Send Status – allows project managers to verify the transmission results and monitor whether the synchronization of dates has been successfully completed. In case of error situations, error message is shown in the project plan header of this application. For more details on this, refer this troubleshooting section in PRM user guide.

Now let’s do some edits to the project plan. Change Project Plan start  date. Add some dependencies between the work packages or milestones by establishing Finish-Start Relationships.

Change project plan settings to scheduling to “Forward Scheduling” for example. And then click on “Schedule” to schedule the project with forward scheduling settings. The dates must have changed for some of the project elements. Once editing is complete and the project plan is saved, any changes made to project plan header or any Work Package (Planned Start, Planned Finish, Actual Start, and Actual Finish dates) or any Milestone(Planned Finish, Actual Finish, and Forecast Finish dates) , either manually or through the Schedule function—are automatically synchronized back to the source project in SAP Cloud ERP.

You can click on “Sync Actions”->”Check Send Status” to verify that the project plan is synchronized with source system. System should show a toast message as shown in screenshot below.

You can verify that the changes are reflected in SAP Cloud ERP system in “Project Planning” application as shown above.

This bi-directional synchronization ensures that both systems remain aligned, supporting consistent and accurate project scheduling across platforms.

Processing Status

In the Manage Project Plans app, the ability to edit project element dates depends on the processing status of the corresponding project in SAP Cloud ERP. You can notice that the processing status from the source project is also brought into the project plan and is shown both in the Project Plan Header and also at the Work package or Milestone level in the project structure. You can modify planned, actual, and forecast dates for both Enterprise Projects and Professional Services Projectswhen the project or the work package has processing status such as Created, Released, Partially Released, In Planning, In Contract Preparation, or In Execution. However, once a project reaches a Completed, Closed, or Locked status, editing of the work package or the milestone under it is no longer allowed.

Conclusion :

By integrating PRM with SAP Cloud ERP, customers can now achieve a truly unified project management experience that enables seamless coordination between planning and execution. This integration facilitates close monitoring of project timelines and milestones, while also providing precise control over project costs and material demands directly within the connected ERP system. As a result, organizations benefit from enhanced visibility, improved resource allocation, and the ability to respond swiftly to changes, ensuring projects are delivered on time and within budget. The synchronized data flow between platforms not only reduces manual effort but also supports informed decision-making, ultimately driving operational efficiency and better business outcomes.

Related API:

Project Plan Service API - to import project from SAP Cloud ERP into PRM:  
For detailed information, refer to the Business Accelerator Hub. 

Related Topics:  

  • Must Start On & Must Finish On Constraints: Define specific constraints on project elements, offering more precise control over scheduling and enhancing project flexibility. - To learn more, see this link: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/date-constraints-in-sap-... 
  • Schedule Projects with SAP Project and Resource Management : To learn more, see this link https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/schedule-projects-with-sap-project-and-resource-management/ba-p/14137576?emcs_t=S2h8ZW1haWx8a3Vkb3N8TUY4MjBUNEZERk9LQkR8MTQxMzc1NzZ8S1VET1N8aEs

Discover more by checking out our website.

entry.title: Prevent approval/rejection of forwarded workflow task when user lacks required profiles
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We have a requirement to prevent users who received a forwarded workflow task in My Inbox from approving or rejecting the task if they do not have the required authorization profiles.

To achieve this, we implemented the BAdI /IWWRK/IF_WF_WI_BEFORE_UPD_IB.
Our logic works correctly in principle — it checks the user’s profiles and returns an error message in CT_RETURN if the authorization is missing. However, the task still gets completed regardless of the error message.

We have noticed that there are standard SAP implementations of this BAdI which already execute the work item before our implementation is called. As a result, even when we return an error message, the action still goes through and the work item is disappears from the inbox.

Question:

Is there a supported way to prevent or cancel the work item execution if our custom implementation detects missing authorization? Or is there a more appropriate BAdI or method (for flexible workflows) where such pre-checks can be implemented?

Any guidance or experience from others who have handled similar requirements would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance for your help!

Anouk

entry.title: Re: Test Suite Dashboard - Custom Fields Implementation
entry.content:
My experience: The usual Mario Jump&Run.

I had two custom fields and created four entries for them: two for DEFECTSTAT and two for DEFECTSTPR.

The generation failed with the useless error message 'Error activating append structure'. So what? I debugged the generation and discovered that the error was reported by FM DDIF_TABL_ACTIVATE for the fourth customizing entry. Indeed structure /SALM/DASH_DETAILS_DEFPRG_CUST was missing the second append. Hm.

 I logoff and login again, and - o wonder - now the structure /SALM/DASH_DETAILS_DEFPRG_CUST had both appends, and the generation was successful.

I had to delete the cache with transaction /IWFND/CACHE_CLEANUP.

But the Test Suite Dashboard showed an empty screen. I looked into transaction /IWFND/ERROR_LOG and found the error message, that the data object of the first custom field already exists.

OK, the IMG documentation told "Field Name: define the unique technical field name of the property" but did not specify the frame of the uniqueness. The maintenance view of the "Properties" table suggests that the key is View/Field Name. Now I understand that "Field Name" has to be unique independently of the View, because they are all thrown into the same service.

I deleted the two entries for DEFECTSTPR and generated again, but [obviously 🙂 - I know SAP ...] the deletion of the customizing did not delete the appends. So I had to delete the appends manually with SE11 (and I also cleaned the trasnport task).

Now I created the two entries for DEFECTSTPR adding a suffix to the field name and generated: Same procedure. First a generation error, then, after logoff and login again a successful generation. After deleting the Model Cache the Test Suite Dashboard showed finally up, and the fields were there.

But obviously still not perfect working. Because one of the two fields has a list of fixed values in the domain. In the Defect App and in the Mass Change the value help works. But not here in the Test Suite ALP. As there is no documentation I just tried out all four filter types (VS, VM, LS, LM) but no one worked. I will create a Case in Sap4Me.

entry.title: Re: How to batch upload G/L accounts in S/4 Public Cloud...
entry.content:
Good day @Grace_Li1 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

Manage G/L Account Master Data, Download Templates, General Ledger Accounting, Chart of Accounts (Two-System Landscape)

To summarise, in public cloud, you can only create and carry out mass maintenance of G/L accounts through the Excel upload functionality in the Manage G/L Accounts Master Data.

However, this upload supports only certain master data attributes such as account number, name, type, and group assignment. It does not allow updating system-controlled or sensitive flags like “Not Used” or others in bulk as you intend to. Therefore, it explains the limitation you are experiencing.

The clean-core approach in public cloud aims to ensure data integrity and audit compliance, which is also another factor in play here.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Clarification on “E/R key diff. balance” Field in FCV App (S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

In the Foreign Currency Valuation (FCV) app in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there is a field called “E/R key diff. balance” (Exchange Rate Key Difference Balance) under the G/L Account Balances tab.

Purpose / Usage As per my understanding-
This field allows you to specify a G/L account that will store the exchange rate difference balance during the foreign currency valuation process.
When FCV runs, SAP recalculates the value of foreign currency balances based on the key date’s exchange rate.
If the rate has changed, the system identifies a gain or loss. Normally, these are posted to gain/loss accounts, but for certain balance sheet accounts (like bank or intercompany accounts), you may want to record revaluation differences separately. That’s where this field is used.

How It Works As per my understanding-
When maintained, the system posts the valuation difference (gain/loss) to the G/L account entered in this field instead of adjusting the main G/L balance — keeping the operational balance and valuation effect clearly separated.

Key Benefits:

  • Keeps FX valuation effects separate for better transparency and auditability
  • Simplifies reconciliation and reporting

Also, as I understand, the setup comes from SSCUI 100297 – “Define Accounts for Exchange Rate Differences” under Auto Account Determination, where keys like Z001 are defined and linked to the relevant G/L accounts.

I just want to validate if this understanding of benefit and configuration is correct and whether there are any additional uses or best practices for this field in Public Cloud.

Thank you for your guidance in advance

Best regards,

Rohini Dutta

entry.title: Re: Lets Send multipart/form-data to external Receiver: CPI to AI App
entry.content:
Hello,

I think, it is more adequate/easy to use a standard library like apache http to obtain the desired results.

Here is a groovy script which produces multipart/form-data for http post of binary file data together with json (change  names of entities as needed):

(I used httpclient5-5.5.1.jar and httpcore5-5.3.5.jar) 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;

import org.apache.hc.client5.http.entity.mime.MultipartEntityBuilder;
import org.apache.hc.core5.http.HttpEntity;
import org.apache.hc.core5.http.ContentType;


def Message processData(Message message) {

def filename = message.getProperty("fileName") as String;

String body = message.getBody();
//get base64 encoded body, decode it as byte array
byte[] barry = org.apache.commons.codec.binary.Base64.decodeBase64(body);
//get json
def jsonReqest = message.getProperty("JsonRequest") as String;
//setup multipart
MultipartEntityBuilder builder = MultipartEntityBuilder.create();
//add json as text entity 
builder.addTextBody("requestData", jsonReqest, ContentType.APPLICATION_JSON);
//add file as binary entity
builder.addBinaryBody("fileContent", barry, ContentType.APPLICATION_OCTET_STREAM, filename);

HttpEntity entity = builder.build();
//set multipart/form-data header
message.setHeader("Content-Type", entity.getContentType());


message.setBody(entity.getContent());

return message;

}

entry.title: Re: Feasibility Check on DMS Integration Requirement
entry.content:
Hello @Maheshk123 

Thank you for your question.

In summary, you can technically integrate attachments from external systems such as Kissflow into SAP DMS. However, because of the public cloud clean-core approach, there are restrictions to directly access the backend file repositories. This means that you must carry out the integration through standard APIs or BTP-based connectors and not by writing directly into SAP tables or content servers.

The clean-core and supported approach in public cloud is for you to leverage SAP DMS through BTP and combine them with the Attachment API available on the Business HUB.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

Documents Integration, Integrating with SAP Document Management Service, Attachments (A2X), DMS-5695: Integration with external systems, Connecting SAP Document Management Service

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Re-Test (Inspection) Date calc
entry.content:
Hi,
By default, SAP calculates the retest date based on the Goods Receipt (GR) date plus the inspection interval. To make the system calculate it from the Manufacturing Date, you need to configure batch management and quality management settings so that the production date (MFG date) is used as the reference instead of GR. This typically requires customizing in batch master data, inspection lot creation, or enhancement via user exits/BAdIs.

entry.title: Re: Automatic create STO from SO
entry.content: In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, automatic creation of a Stock Transport Order from a Sales Order is not a standard “out‑of‑the‑box” function. To achieve this, you need to configure cross‑plant stock determination and supply assignment so that when the sales order is confirmed in plant 11DC, the system recognizes stock availability in plant 11DA and triggers a replenishment process (via purchase requisition → STO). This typically requires Advanced ATP (aATP) with Alternative Plant Assignment and MRP‑based STO creation rather than a direct SD‑to‑MM link.

entry.content:
Hi,
In SAP, you cannot simply switch a material from non-batch-managed to batch-managed if stock already exists — SAP requires that all stock be cleared first. Without batch management, the only way to track each product individually is to use serial number management instead of batch management

SAP restriction: Once stock exists for a material, you cannot activate batch management in the material master until that stock is consumed or cleared.

Standard process: Clear unrestricted and reserved stock. Change material master to batch managed. Re-post stock with batch numbers (via MIGO).

This is why your scenario (with 300 materials and 8000 finished products) is problematic — clearing stock is not feasible

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Factoring Process witho...
entry.content:
Hi @byd ,

I've not used this flow - but did some research for app equivalences etc. and the output is as below. Please review carefully for your scenario to see if it gets you what you need:

Corrected App Mapping:

  • Customer Invoicing: Use "Create Customer Invoice" app (not F-22)
  • Manual Journal Entry: Use "Create Journal Entry" app (replaces FB01)
  • Incoming Payments: Use "Post Incoming Payments" app (replaces F-28)
  • Outgoing Payments: Use "Post Outgoing Payments" app (replaces F-53)
  • Manual Clearing: Use "Clear G/L Account" app (replaces F1579)

Detailed Implementation Steps

Step 1: Invoice Creation (Feb 10)

  • App: Create Customer Invoice
  • Posting:
    • DR: Customer Account ¥1,000,000
    • CR: Revenue Account ¥1,000,000

Step 2: Factoring Transaction (Mar 10)

  • App: Create Journal Entry
  • Posting:
    • DR: Bank Account ¥900,000
    • DR: Factoring Fee Expense ¥100,000
    • CR: Customer Account ¥1,000,000
  • Note: This directly clears the customer AR while recording the factoring fee

Step 3: Customer Payment Receipt (Apr 15)

  • App: Create Journal Entry (not Post Incoming Payments)
  • Posting:
    • DR: Bank Account ¥1,000,000
    • CR: Deposits Payable/Trust Account ¥1,000,000
  • Rationale: Since the AR is already cleared, use journal entry rather than incoming payments

Step 4: Transfer to Factoring Company (Apr 16)

  • App: Post Outgoing Payments or Create Journal Entry
  • Posting:
    • DR: Deposits Payable ¥1,000,000
    • CR: Bank Account ¥1,000,000

Key Considerations

Account Setup Requirements:

  • Create a "Deposits Payable" or "Trust Account" G/L account
  • Set up a "Factoring Fee Expense" G/L account
  • Ensure proper bank account configuration for multiple cash flows

Process Validation:

  • The manual journal entry in Step 2 can indeed clear customer-specific AR directly
  • No additional clearing process needed if postings are structured correctly
  • Consider implementing approval workflows for manual journal entries

Alternative Approach: If direct AR clearing via journal entry faces restrictions, consider:

  1. Use "Post Incoming Payments" in Step 2 with a clearing account
  2. Post the factoring fee separately via journal entry
  3. Use clearing functions to match the transactions
